div.h1: Gender ideology and identity in humorous social media memes

div.div:
Department of English and Literary Studies, Federal University Oye-Ekiti,
Nigeria
Correspondence: Victoria O. Gbadegesin, Department of English and Literary Studies, Federal University Oye-Ekiti, Nigeria. E-mail:victoria.ogunkunle@fuoye.edu.ng
Search for other works by this author on:
Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 35, Issue 3, September 2020, Pages 529–546, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqz039

div.p: Victoria O Gbadegesin, Gender ideology and identity in humorous social media memes, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 35, Issue 3, September 2020, Pages 529–546, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqz039

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: This study investigates ‘otherness’ in gender identity creation in social media memes. Nineteen ‘Correct Bro’ and ‘Correct Bae’ memes from Facebook are purposively selected for the study. The analysis is qualitative in approach and is anchored on Incongruity Theory of humour and Gender Social Theory. Linguistic tools from Critical Stylistics are employed for the linguistic interpretation of the data. Specific gender otherness identified are the dependent other, irrational other, opportunistic other, weak other, and the unreal other. Humorous forms identified are parody, teasing, pun, and sarcasm among others. Otherness is constructed within these humorous forms with linguistic and rhetorical tools, such as structural opposition, lexical absence, prioritizing, repetition, and so on. The study identified that gender ‘otherness’ is expressed in humorous memes to either reinforce existing gender ideologies or challenge them. Also, humorous memes are not just created to evoke laughter but are tools for expressing new tendencies in gender ideological orientation in the society.

div.p: Humour is described as anything that is ‘funny, amusing, or laughable’ (Attardo, 2011). It has escapist tendencies and often lightens the mood of individuals by providing relief from pain. While humour is being engaged globally, African scholars have found humour studies interesting and engaging with the exploration of different forms and contexts of humour usage. Such studies explore issues as socio-cultural improvisation in Africa (Obadare, 2010), hilarity and the Nigerian condition (Afolayan, 2013), remediation of trickster hero on social media, (Yékú, 2016), reader’s response to humour (Filani, 2016), and contextual beliefs and pragmatic strategies in online humour (Adeoti and Filani, 2016) among others. These studies have established that humour is integral to discursive events even in the English as Second Language environment and serve many purposes, including ideological ones. However, not so much attention has been given to the ideological representations and identity enabled by humour in social media memes. Apart from provoking laughter, humour performs other serious functions in many communicative events especially in digital communication which has often been associated with humour, joking, language play, role play, and others (Vandergriff, 2010). Humour is used to open up many destabilizing and subversive possibilities (Holoch, 2012) and as a means of rebellion, resistance to tyranny, or as compensation for defeat (Vandergriff, 2010).

The virtual space is a microcosm of the human society, where several communicative strategies and media are explored to lend voices to topical issues in the society. Many narratives are deliberately created on the social media to address specific concerns about the socio-political or socio-cultural situation of the society. Some of these narratives are political, while others address more sociological and cultural issues, such as gender representation and perception, identity creation, child marriage, and related issues. One of the tools used by narrators on the social media is meme that could be manipulated images with catch-phrases, videos, viral posts, and so on. It is a very important communicative resource on the social media with dense language and vivid imageries. The power of a meme lies in its ability to go viral and the ease in its recreation enabled by its funny contents.

More often than not, humour is employed as a strategy on social media to mask ideological representations. This enables humorous narratives enjoy wider acceptability despite their offensive, cynical, and sometimes sarcastic undertones. Humorous memes are associated with post-colonial humour which according to Yékú (2016) achieves more caustic emphasis. While serving as a medium of release and therefore a relief from inner anxieties and a means of reconstructing social, political, and cultural narratives, such humorous narratives enable media users to be entertained at the expense of the ‘other’ in the cyber communities; the ‘other’ being an exclusive term for members of the out-group in relation to the in-group. With the proliferation of humorous narratives, media users subtly challenge dominant paradigms, reconstruct, and reappropriate them where necessary. Such challenge and reconstruction are confirmed by Onadeko (2010) when he affirms that despite the patriarchal nature of many African societies, there are modifications to the male superiority ideology on the social media. It is against this background that this study examines gender-centred Correct Bro and Correct Bae memes with the aim of exploring how humour is used to legitimize and/or challenge existing gender paradigms in Nigeria while also exploring the ‘other’ identities created to sustain or challenge the status quo.

Memes are important meaning making artefacts created, and spread through the social media. They are referred to as forms of popular culture and post-modern folklore (Shifman, 2011). The word ‘meme’ was coined and first used by Richard Dawkins in The Selfish Gene (Dawkins, 1976). He compared the way ideas evolve to the evolution of genes and refers to memes as replicating entities produced by human culture and transmitted through language. He reaffirms this when he states that they are self-replicating units of culture (Dawkins, 1999). Although Dawkins did not particularly associate memes with the social media, it has been adopted by ‘the online world to describe a kind of running joke based around a particular idea’ (Concannon, 2011). According to him, memes are created from some kind of local sites but spread through the Internet. Usually memes reproduce themselves or are reproduced as they continue to go viral on the Internet. They are sometimes embellished with some superimposed catch-phrases. Brugioni (1999) highlights the purpose of the manipulation as removing details, inserting details, photo-managing contents, and false captioning. All these are done to make the content humorous and ultimately appealing for wide sharing.

In general, it is believed that memes can be anything as photo, a video, a person, an animal, a fictional character, an event, a song, a belief, an action, a GIF, a symbol, a word, or anything else (Moreau, 2017) and stories, recipes, skills, legends, or fashion which we copy one at a time or which reproduce themselves (Gleick, 2011). However, there are characteristics expected of memes, which are defined differently by scholars. For some, memes are catchy, have the replicating and propagating power of ideas or phenomena on the social media (Knobel and Lankshear, 2007; Bauckhage, 2011; Milner, 2013). They are believed to promulgate in the meme pool through imitation by leaping from brain to brain and also platforms to platforms with highly shareable contents (Nasri, 2012).

In another view, the humour in memes gives them the meme status (Davison, 2012; Chandler, 2013; Plevriti, 2014; Moreau, 2017 ). Plevriti (2014) states that memes are known for their entertainment purposes, which are derived from the humour with which they exist. According to Concannon (2011), contents go viral because they are funny, shocking, or just interesting. So, for him, humour gives ideas or phenomena the meme status because it makes them go viral. This reinforces the fact that humour is central to the creation and proliferation of memes. Hofer and Swan (2005) also allude to the humorous nature of memes, although with negative undertone when they state that while memes (manipulated images) are ‘humorous and often used for comedic purposes, the potential for more damaging fabrications is clear and troubling’ (Hofer and Swan, 2005, p. 292). This alludes to another important quality of memes, which is its effect on social media users. For Hofer and Swan (2005), the effect can be negative since they have potentials for damaging fabrications. Dennett (1998) and Gleick (2011) reinforce the fact that meme have far reaching effects by stating that memes are information-packets with attitudes that have differential effects in the world and they have very powerful effects that are far-reaching in the world, respectively. Dennett suggests that memes’ presence, like viruses, can lower or increase the fitness of their human hosts (manipulated images) or can be neutral without any serious effect.

This study aligns with the fact that memes have effects on culture even though Dennett does not totally believe human vectors are aware of such effects. These include the preservation and replication of cultural paradigms. Social media platforms through memes create agencies for the representation of self and other identities in relation to existing paradigms while also opening up capacities to challenge and realign these paradigms to new and emergent cultures. The affirmation of Brunello (2012) that the end result of spreading memes through the new technology is a globally shared ideology or world culture implies that memes are vehicles for culture proliferation. This study investigates memes as artefacts capable of encoding gender ideologies and identities with the specific goal of explicating how gender ‘othering’ is achieved through humorous memes.

Humour is a multidimensional and a multidisciplinary phenomenon with scholars from philosophy, psychology, linguistics, literature, and sociology among others exploring it from different perspectives. As a social and communicative activity, humour is generally believed to elicit laughter and gaiety, and is mostly perceived as funny. Scheel and Gockel (2017, p. 12) are of the opinion that ‘there is no fully satisfactory comprehensive definition of humour but scholars agree that humour involves the communication of multiple, incongruous meanings that are amusing in some manner’. It is perceived as capable of eliciting positive feelings (Hurren, 2006), and so is a crucial element in social interactions ( Collins, 2004; Friedman and Kuipers, 2013 ). It is also a rhetorical tool that is pervasive, pleasant, and persuasive (Meyer, 2000). For Scheel and Gockel (2017, p. 9), humour ‘includes the abilities to produce, recognize, and appreciate humour and to use humour as a coping strategy’. This aligns with Martin’s (2007) definition of humour as the ability to understand, express and appreciate jokes and humorous comments, and to actively seek sources that elicit laughter. Scheel and Gockel (2017) and Martin (2007) agree that humour can be used as a coping mechanism. The definitions above establish the interactional and social functions of humour.

Beyond its description as a social and communicative event, humour is essentially cognitive especially when considering the trigger for laugher in funny situations. The theory of humour related to cognition is the incongruity theory. Incongruity is considered integral to humour (Martin, 2007) and is often applied to linguistic investigations because it accounts for the cognitive and pragmatic processes underpinning the understanding of humorous texts (Dynel, 2013). Singh (2012, p. 65) describes humour as ‘the recognition and expression of incongruities or peculiarities present in a situation or character’. Many other scholars agree that incongruity is a prerequisite for jokes (Dynel, 2011). Generally, incongruity relates to ‘something unexpected, out of context, inappropriate, unreasonable, illogical, and exaggerated’ (McGhee, 1979, p. 10). Incongruity theory states that laughter situations occur when there is a contradiction between expectations and experiences. Hence, there is a violation of an expected pattern, which brings surprise and then elicits laughter. Grunner (1997) believes that incongruity theory presents two objects in a joke through a single frame, which is then applied to both objects to make them similar. Dynel (2013) avers that incongruity recognition is facilitated when it lies between elements that are globally believed to be contradictory. Hence, the two objects in a single frame suggested by Grunner (1997) do not usually align together, but are placed in a single frame to make them similar for the purpose of eliciting laughter. For Attardo (1997), incongruity is discovered in marked and unmarked linguistic expressions when they are placed in opposition to each other. Giora’s (2003) description of incongruity as graded salience also alludes to the fact that the framing of the two elements presented in a joke or humorous event makes it stand out and often elicits laughter. From these descriptions, it is clear that there is usually a violation of expectations in humorous events and this violation is situated in a single frame of two elements not usually conceived as similar but made similar to elicit laughter. The frame can either be a knowledge frame that relates to the organization of knowledge or interactional frame always oriented towards a particular goal. Therefore, humour in incongruity theory is dependent on the ability of the hearer to recognize inconsistencies in humorous expressions or situations and resolve it.

Wilkins and Eisenbraun (2009) postulate that incongruity emphasizes cognition because a pattern of reality needs to be established before incongruity is identified in a humorous situation. While there are arguments as to how many incongruous situations are humorous, Dynel (2011, p. 4) asserts that ‘incongruity is humorous only if followed by a resolution’. This leads to an important aspect of a humour, which is the punch line. Dynel (2013) asserts that a joke has a build-up/set-up and a punch line. Where the build-up provides information about the character, setting, and time of the story and also raises expectations, the punch line closes the joke by producing a sudden and an unexpected incongruity not consistent with the expectation built up earlier. There are two variations of incongruity resolution theory, which are the Surprise Disambiguation Model (SDM) advanced by Ritchie (1999) and two-stage model (2SM) espoused by Suls (1972, 1983). SDM proposes that jokes are explained based on one very obvious interpretation and another less obvious interpretation, which is only clear after the punch line conflicts with the obvious interpretation and evokes the other meaning. The 2SM talks about two phases of a joke, where the first phase produces expectations and the second phase delivers a punch line not consistent with the expectations. In the two approaches, the jokes draw upon incongruous punch line and covert ambiguity. Therefore, the reader/listener always needs a cognitive skill to reread the humorous texts and resolve the incongruity in the punch line.

Incongruity is seen as an integral strategy for creating humour in Correct Bro and Correct Bae memes. The meme creators initiate cognitive responses to the humour by allowing the punch line of the jokes to clash with the build-up. Therefore, the incongruity theory in its broad sense is applied to the data for the purpose of highlighting their humorous content.

Gender is a very important aspect of human life yet almost invisible because it is taken for granted in our relationship and language use. ‘Almost all aspects of our lives are gendered’ (Burr, 1998), and in our modern and complex societies, gendered images are disseminated through different institutions and the media (Cavender et al., 1999). Gender is a tool for dismantling perceived differences used to legitimize observed disparities in gender social order (Budgeon, 2014). As a social variable, it has varying linguistic manifestations in different contexts of language use. Dobash et al. (1998) agree that media reproduce gender stereotypes.

Gender, therefore, is a socio-cultural construct often described in relation to prevailing social ideologies and gendered practices are informed by gender ideologies that Shitemi (2009, p. 4) explains as ‘a system of beliefs by which people explain, account for and justify their behaviour’. Gender ideologies also inform and guide the interpretation and assessment of the behaviour of others while setting the norms that govern participation in the gender order and by which they explain and justify participation. Language is the key instrument and medium by which gender ideologies are constructed, perpetuated, and propagated. Generally, women are believed to be dominated by men (Burr, 1998) even in the media (Carter and Steiner, 2004). However, Holly (2005) and Onadeko (2010) claim that the reality in gender media representation is continuously being re-constructed, re-challenged, and reoriented as the world progresses such that there is tension between the two sexes and their representations on social media as new paradigms challenging the discourse of power are emerging. This trend in gender studies reaffirms that gender is socially constructed and is context bound because different context of language use produce different gender identities although all are informed by the prevailing gender ideologies in the society. Cavender et al. (1999) state that the media play an important role in the depiction of gender as a social construction. Also, Bing (2007) and Kotthoff (2007) attest to the fact that there are new tendencies in gendered humour and joking in conversations and interactions evident in the subversion of prevalent gender order and gender roles. This implies that apart from the fact that humour provides a site for the construction and display of gender identities (Thielemann, 2011), it also projects new trends and in gender identity construction. This, however, has not received much scholarly attention. Thielemann (2011) fills this gap by investigating the display of new genders in Russian jokes using jokes on social media platforms. This study extends the concerns to social media humorous memes with the aim of investigating othering as a strategy for creating gendered identities on the platform.

Among many theories relating to gender studies are social theory of gender proposed by Connell (1987, 1995), and social constructionism whose tenets are employed in the present study. The theory provides for the conceptualization of gender ‘othering’ in a patriarchal society. Connell theorizes that symbolic gender boundaries are maintained through hegemonic masculinity and emphasized femininity where hegemonic masculinity is perceived as gender practices that legitimize male dominance and female subordination in any society and emphasized femininity as characterized by female submission, and passivity among others. Social constructionism, on the other hand, perceives gender, like other characteristics thought to be biological, as human definitions informed by cultural and historical contexts, which encompass the linguistic dealings of people. The study emphasizes that the pattern found in the speech of a gender about the other is informed by prevailing ideologies in the society. Hence, dominant ideologies that underlie gender relations and constructions birth the principle of ‘otherness’, which is a defining concept in gender studies employed by feminists, such as Simone de Beauvoir and Friedman, to describe the position of women in a patriarchal society. They argue that the female gender is defined from the male perspective through the fundamental categorization of ‘otherness’. Therefore, the woman is the incidental and the inessential as against the purposeful and the essential man.

‘Otherness’ is also defined as a post-colonial concept against which ‘self’ is defined (Cole, 2004), while ‘Othering’ is ‘a process through which identities are set up in an unequal relationship’ (Crang, 1998, p. 61). Through this process, in-group and out-group are created where in-group embodies the norm and valued identity and the out-group is defined by their fault, and so are devalued and susceptible to discrimination (Staszak, 2008). Therefore, ‘othering sets up a superior self/in-group in contrast to an inferior other/out-group, but this superiority/inferiority is nearly always left implicit’ (Brons, 2015, p. 70). The ‘Other’ is always a member of the out-group whose inferior identity is created in different narratives through distorted experiences and realities. ‘Otherness’ is a means of expressing ideological stances and constructing identities (Mineva, 2015). A group or persons only maintain their superior identit(ies) by referring to another group as ‘other’ through a hierarchical relationship favouring the first at the expense of the other (Cahoone, 2003). Because this process is usually neutralized and made inherent to phenomena and narratives, it is ideologically oriented.

Although the concept of ‘otherness’ was first used by colonizing culture to describe the colonized and has essentially being used to categorize women in gender studies, it has since been attributed to any self-other identity creation be it political, gender, religious, racial, or social among others. This study explores ‘othering’ in Correct Bro and Correct Bae memes as linguistic expressions of dominant ideologies and a means of creating identities. The study aligns with Staszak (2008) that ‘otherness’ is related to identity and ideology.

The data for this study are samples of gender related Correct Bro and Correct Bae memes from Facebook. Nineteen memes are purposively selected in all with ten from Correct Bro and Nine from Correct Bae memes. The selection is purposive because not all Correct Bro and Correct Bae memes are centred on gender issues. ‘Bro’ and ‘Bae’ in Nigeria are tags for the male and female youths, respectively, and are often used in jocular or informal situations. Correct Bro memes are created as the male voice on social media, while Correct Bae memes serve as the female counterpart on social media. Some Correct Bro memes capture gender issues through humorous texts centred on both genders, while gender based Correct Bae memes are targeted at liberating the female gender through the use of humorous relationship advice for women and sarcasm for the male gender. The use of ‘correct’ with bro and bae implies being smart and savvy. Incongruity Theory of humour and gender Social Theory serve as anchors for the study and linguistic tools and strategies in Jeffries’ (2010) Critical Stylistics are employed for the linguistic interpretation of the data. The analysis of the data is qualitative. The linguistic analysis of humour and identities are anchored specifically on equivalence, negation, repetition, prioritizing, hypothesizing, interrogation, word choices, and structural opposition, and lexical absence among others as found in the data.

The analysis unravels how the male and female genders create and propagate the ‘other’ identity using memes on social media. Social media users are social actors and are group participants who maybe in-group or out-group participants. The social media as a context of production is constitutive of social structures, which reflect in discourses on them. The major social structure considered in this analysis is the gender social structure. This consists of the perception of a gender and the attitude of that gender to the other. The ‘other’ identity identified in the data is analyzed below:

Dependency is usually associated with a person who cannot survive on his/her own but needs the support of another. In hegemonic masculinity, dependency is associated with the female gender and the meme creators here reproduce the ideology by associating this attribute to the female gender, thereby creating the dependent other identity for them.

Figures 1–3 establish the various areas of life that women are viewed as dependants. In Fig. 1, women are portrayed as always dependent on men to get them out of trouble, which makes them social dependants. There is the use of salience in the capitalization of ‘facts’ to reinforce the information about women in the meme. The meme creator uses strategic generalization in the choice of the indefinite article ‘a’ with woman. This generalization implies that the identity is for every woman. Also, the repetition of ‘she’ is used as a rhetorical strategy for emphasis, while quasi-structural opposition as seen in ‘help’ and ‘trouble’ supports the we versus them ideology. Incongruity in the humour comes to the fore with the punch line ‘remember when in trouble again’. This presents the woman as ungrateful and an opportunist who will forget to appreciate but remember her helper only when in trouble again. Lexical absence is used to highlight the effect of what the woman will remember and this defeats the expectation of gratitude built up from the first part of the text. Women here are presented as troublemakers and the men as problem-solvers. This is corroborated by Fig. 2, where the sexual dependant identity is subtly created for the female gender. The text producer chooses the progressive form of ‘use’ to present the woman as the active agent preying of an unsuspecting male. The choice of ‘warm up’ situates the action in the context of cold weather. This implies that the woman has power to use a man to her advantage whenever she thinks she needs him. However, the text presupposes that a woman sometimes needs a man for sexual gratification. The meme creator uses the static verb ‘know’ which also indicates a mental process to express the absoluteness of his opinion. Another ‘other’ identity is created for the male ‘used’ by the female. The attribute ‘young’ as used in the text encodes naivety that is believed to have been exploited by the female character. Therefore, the text is produced to caution unsuspecting young men about the sexual dependency and exploitation of women with the goal of presenting the female gender as dependants who needs men for sexual satisfaction but dump them after using them for the said purpose.
Women as social dependants
Women as social dependants

img.alt: Women as sexual dependants and men as unsuspecting victims

div.p: Women as sexual dependants and men as unsuspecting victims

img.alt: Women as sexual dependants and men as unsuspecting victims

div.p: Women as sexual dependants and men as unsuspecting victims
Women as marital dependants
Women as marital dependants

The dependant identity for women is further established in Fig. 3, where the texts alludes to the dependence of women on men for marital fulfilment. There are two frames in the joke but the two are linked together to create an extensive build-up for the joke intended. The meme creator uses specificity to identify the objects of his joke with the choice of the demonstrative determiner ‘those’ and the pronoun ‘you’. This implies that the joke is not targeted at all females but those ‘who do not reply messages’. The use of the negator ‘not’ is to provoke a derisive feeling in the reader about the action attributed to the specific females. The punch line is the incongruous hypothetical response given to a form of greeting. The meme creator uses register clash in the punch line to create humour. This implies that a woman may enjoy power because of her beauty and attractiveness for a while but the reality of the necessity of a man in her life will soon make her desperate such that any move from any man is interpreted as interest in marrying her. The underlying ideology is that a woman is created for a man, and marriage is presented as the ultimate goal of a woman. This emanates from hegemonic masculinity, where men are seen as the indispensable in-group and women as the insignificant ‘other’.
div.h4: 5.2.1 This aspect analyses the construction of irrational ‘other’ identity for both genders
div.p: The ‘other’ identity in Fig. 4 is among the male gender. The text producer creates an in-group and an out-group among men using analogy. Specificity as captured in the use of the pronouns ‘you and your’ is used as a strategy for identifying the social actor that belongs to the out-group. There are two unrelated elements within the humorous frame, which are a box of pizza and a bag of cement. A similarity is established between them through the price of the two, which contributes to the build-up of the joke. The punch line that is the last sentence is incongruous in the sense that mansion is presented as food that can be consumed. With the punch line, the reader needs to reread the text to resolve the incongruity created through covert ambiguity in the text. There is the use of prioritizing as a strategy to establish who the person in control is and who the victim is. By fronting side chicks, they are presented as the ones in control of a loose man’s wealth while the man is the victim. While the texts appear jocular, it is created as a form of resistance to wealth control. The Correct Bro meme creator uses the joke as a sensitization for men to retain their dominant position by being in charge of their wealth and using it to acquire properties, which can emphasize their masculinity. This corroborates the definition of humour by Lynch (2002) as ‘either as a mechanism of control or a form of resistance’.
Loose men as the stupid ‘other’
Loose men as the stupid ‘other’

Irrationality is associated with an out-group among the female gender in Fig. 5. ‘Slay queen’ is a slangy expression used for ladies who show off beauty and affluence at the slightest opportunity, but are believed to accentuate their physical appearance as a cover-up for lacking in some areas which could be wealth, beauty, intelligence, and so on. While they always appear beautiful and attractive, they are seen as fake. The humour in Fig. 5 is premised on the negativity associated with slay queens. The image of burnt boiled eggs equating fried eggs for slay queens because she is used to frying groundnuts suggests that despite her appearance that usually is attractive, she is irrational, hence, cannot engage in deductive reasoning. Fake identity for the slay queen emerges from her job captured in the action verb ‘sell’ and the object ‘groundnut, with the presentation of herself as a slay queen. Hypothesizing is a central linguistic strategy used in creating the joke and the recipient is supposed to be a man specifically identified with ‘you’. The meme creator uses pun word play and ambiguity to establish the inability of the lady to disambiguate the expression ‘fry’ and put it in context to avoid error. The build-up of the joke is found in the written text, while the punch line is captured in the image of the burnt boiled eggs. From a gender perspective, the humour is targeted at women to puncture the arrogance that may arise from being a trendy woman (slay queen). It is driven by the same hegemonic masculinity which emphasizes female weakness as against male dominance.
Women as illogical beings
Women as illogical beings

Figure 6 captures the theme of jealousy from the female gender. The voice in the text is that of a male who deliberately provokes his ex to jealousy by giving her the impression that he has other women giving him sexual pleasure when there is none. The choice of the verbs ‘want’ and ‘to spoil’ with ‘I’ implies that the action is deliberate and the ‘I’ captures the fact that the man is in control of the ex’s emotion. The punch line in the joke is going to the pharmacy many times to buy condom and expecting the ex to be jealous. This contradicts normal reasoning because buying condom many times does not translate to having sex as many times. However, the man believes he can provoke the lady to jealousy because the woman is not expected to engage in any critical thinking which may reveal the intention of the man. The meme suggests that a woman is by nature jealous and irrational and the man establishes his power by controlling the emotion of the woman, which is an inherent feature of hegemonic masculinity.
Women as the jealous other
Women as the jealous other

The gender order in social gender theory attributes aggression, dominance, promiscuity, and self-reliance among others to the male gender. These place the gender in a position of authority, which could take advantage of the other gender. While the female gender is presented as passive and submissive, the data below reveal that they conceive men as opportunists, thereby creating the ‘other’ identity for them.

In Fig. 7, the ‘other’ identity is created for a group of girls who are identified through equivalence as seen in the use of ‘are’ as single. The meme creator employs irony to establish how their liberality in relationships translates to their singleness; hence, their ability to give everything amounts to them having nothing while the men that receive everything give nothing. The incongruity in the joke is found in the ironical situation in which after giving everything to a man, a lady remains single. Within this identity construction, the meme creator emphasize the opportunistic nature of men. A parallel is drawn between the two genders with the use of structural parallelism and repetition of ‘a lot of’. The punch line of the joke is in the last clause that states a clash between the content of the build-up and the punch line. The joke is targeted at females who give everything to win a man but end up being single because the men simply enjoy what the girls have to offer without getting committed to them. The joke is satirical, it makes fun of the ‘kind and soft’ nature of the female gender with the hope of getting them to be firmer when relating with the male gender.
Women as liberal partners
Women as liberal partners

Figure 8 addresses men and promiscuity. The meme reinforces the opportunist identity for men by stating that they exploit being jilted and use it as an opportunity to trap and have sex with many women. The humour in the text is premised on euphemism as seen in the use of John Thomas and hole as euphemisms for penis and vagina. The punch line is the expression ‘Weldon sir’. However, the expectation from the build-up is not a commendation as captured in the facial expressions on the meme showing disapproval. The meme creator uses irony in the mock commendation ‘weldon sir’ to express disapproval. The deliberate use of pidgin foregrounds the mock commendation and the intended sarcasm. The expression is context bound because it is a direct translation of many indigenous sarcastic commendation aimed at cautioning another person about a particular action. Since the meme creator represents the female gender, she condemns promiscuity that is attributed to men under hegemonic masculinity. The implication is that the text producer is conscious of the gender order that reinforce male dominance in the society and refuses to be complicit by deliberately challenging it.

img.alt: Men as promiscuous and men as opportunists

div.p: Men as promiscuous and men as opportunists

img.alt: Men as promiscuous and men as opportunists

div.p: Men as promiscuous and men as opportunists

Figure 9 creates a stupid identity for men as captured in the word ‘stupidity’. There is the use of code-mixing with the Yoruba translation of stupidity (agbaya) to reinforce the identity created. The act of thanking a minor for accepting a friend's request on Facebook while being unable to appreciate a wife is equated to stupidity. The meme creator uses contrast to establish the humour in the text. Attributing stupidity to the appreciation in the first phase of the text does not seem justifiable until the punch line, which provides the explanation for the labelling, is introduced. Therefore, the reader of the joke only understands the meaning of the identity created after reading the whole text. The identity is reinforced by the facial expression and the emoticons used to depict scepticism and anger. Here, the meme creator tries to fight the ideology of male superiority, which comes to play in their inability to show appreciation to their wives. The fact that the meme creator expects the male gender to express appreciation is already a challenge to hegemonic masculinity, where women are conceived as incidental and subordinate to men. Figure 10 presents men as sex predators. The identity is premised on the punch line of the joke, which provides an incongruous explanation for the action in the build-up. By using the expression ‘always online without posting anything’, the meme creator establishes a contradiction in the action of the male actor and people’s expectation because being online is often equated to sending posts on different social media platforms. However, the meme creator raises an expectation of a better engagement online through the use of ‘they are busy’ but provides an incongruous explanation which contradicts expectations with the expression ‘begging girls to come to their house’. This is the punch line of the joke from which the sex predator identity emerges. The joke is a sarcasm intended to ridicule men who engage in such act. The joke puts men in the other category through the negative identity created for them. It also implies that the female gender are becoming conscious of the atrocities men are capable of performing because of the established gender paradigm and are beginning to raise consciousness among themselves to be wary of such actions of men.
Men as stupid
Men as stupid
Men as sexual predators
Men as sexual predators
The analysis here explains how both genders create the weak identity for the other to emphasize domination or challenge existing gender order.

Unequal power relation between the genders is seen in Fig. 11 and this informs the construction of the weak identity for the female gender. The power relation is seen in the expression ‘Any guy dating my future wife’. Here, it is the guy that is performing the action of ‘dating’ not the other way round. The use of ‘any’ as a determiner indicates non-specificity, which implies that the message is for whoever is dating the female. Also repetition is used in the build-up to indicate the seriousness of the conversation. However, the message ends with an appeal in pidgin. The sudden switch from the very serious disposition to appeal defeats the expectations built in the first phase of the text, thereby making the punch line incongruous. Also, there is the use of ‘my’, a possessive pronoun to show ownership of the woman and the expression ‘take it easy on her’ to show that the man presently dating the woman has power over her. Here, the woman is objectified as something that can be possessed and presented as the dominated who is unable to help herself, hence the appeal on her behalf. Unequal power relation that places the man at the centre and the woman at the margin is been re-presented in the joke and this is a feature of hegemonic masculinity. Figures 12 and 13 are parodic and punnable comments centred on the ego of men. They are deliberate attempt to puncture the ego and make the man in question feel less than a man. In Fig. 12, the meme creator uses parody to subvert the boost that certain range of men’s height gives to their ego. The meme creator employs a number of strategies in the joke to establish the humour. The first strategy is hypothesizing indicated by the use of ‘if’. It is a negotiating strategy that reduces imposition and equivalence is also used to reinforce the attribute ‘shortness’. ‘You are short’ is a declarative statement showing that the expression is a statement of fact. There is also the use of repetition of the same expression, which accentuates the tease in the humour. The insertion of ‘believe it’ in between the repeated declaration is meant to persuade the recipient to believe the declaration. The choice of the expression ‘high heels can’t rescue you’ alludes to the fact that short women can remedy their shortness using high heels but men do not have that kind of advantage. This creates subtle comparison between the male and female gender in which the woman has an advantage over the man. By stating the inches with which a man is described as short and creating humour out of it, the meme creator establishes that women seem to have the power to determine a man that is attractive to them in terms of his height. The punch line is the incongruous solution to shortness suggested by the woman and the allusion to the socio-cultural contextual belief that eating beans makes one tall. It is clear that the meme is meant to tease the male gender as there are elements of provocation and impertinence mixed together.
Women as the weak other
Women as the weak other
Men as the weak other
Men as the weak other
Men as the weak other
Men as the weak other

Meme in Fig. 13 reinforces the conception of men as weak by creating humour and trivializing jilting, which ordinarily could cause serious emotional trauma for men. The meme plays on the idea and the homophonic nature of ‘bae’ and ‘gone’ on the one hand and Baygon (a brand of insecticide) on the other. It is sarcasm created to tease men whom women are brave to abandon and a counter-narrative to the established societal construct on relationships especially in hegemonic societies where men decide what happens in a relationship. The meme creator redirects the narrative to accommodate new gender paradigms where the female gender has the power to influence decisions that affect her. The meme creator seems to applaud the act of a woman abandoning a man because it indicates that women are challenging male dominance. Figure 14 is a parody meant to ridicule the perceived vanity of women about pleasurable activities like taking pictures. The meme creator sees the poses of women when taking pictures as a defect that can be compared to polio, an epidemic disease in Africa capable of making children lame or handicapped in different ways. This comparison as indicated by asterisk is the punch line of the joke because it is sudden and unexpected. By using the expression ‘it is natural’, the meme creator generalizes the perceived vanity to all women and implies that posing for pictures is a defect, which manifests in femininity. Humour in the meme is premised on teasing the female gender and is evident in the incongruous comparison of a serious ailment as polio and taking pictures. While posing for pictures is not peculiar to the female gender, the text makes mockery of women engaged in the act to de-emphasize femininity so as to project male superiority.
Women as vain
Women as vain

The text in Fig. 15 presents women as having physical fake identity. The creator of the meme gives the impression that unless a woman is without make-up, one does not really know the true look of the woman. There is the use of the first person singular pronoun by the male actor to present himself as the performer of the action encoded in ‘propose’ and ‘make’. This implies that the male actor is in charge of the situation. The first sentence is a complex sentence, where the first clause encodes the action based on the premise in the second clause. The punch line is introduced with a question meant to help the reader to understand the logic of the action intended in the first sentence. Women cosmetics are presented as a mask that prevents the revelation of a woman’s true identity. Hence, women wearing make-up are physically fake with an appearance different from their real self. The meme also has the undertone of unequal power relation between the male and the female gender. Marriage proposal is presented as a favour for the female gender; therefore, the gender is defined in relation to marriage.
Women as physically unreal
Women as physically unreal

Figure 16 captures the attitude of men to ladies they love to remain in a relationship with. The text reveals the creation of ‘other’ identity for men who feign carefulness just to please such female. The text producer uses capitalization for ‘sms’ to draw attention to the jocular frame. The use of ‘a new catch’ presupposes that men prey on women and gaining the attention of one translates to victory for the man. To achieve this victory, the man acts circumspectly. Ellipsis is used after ‘new catch’ in the meme to allow extensive interpretation of the phrase by the reader. There is also the undertone that the disposition is temporary and the true nature of men will be revealed the moment the woman no longer falls into the category of ‘a new catch’. The punch line of the joke is captured in checking the spelling of ‘is’ which sounds extreme to the reader of the text.
Men as social unreal
Men as social unreal

Figure 17 emphasizes the hedonistic nature of some men which gives then the fake ‘other’ identity. The meme creator reveals that some men are given to pleasure through the contextual setting, which is a club. The choice of action words ‘pumping’ and ‘spraying’ with bottles and strippers, respectively, corroborates this fact. The verbs are used in their progressive form to indicate that the actions are continuous and habitual. The choice of the coordinator ‘but’ to connect the sentences shows that the information in the second sentence is contradictory to the first. The second sentence is a complex sentence with the subordinate clause supplying information about the time the real identity of such men comes to the fore. The main clause encodes the action that reveals the contradiction between who the men are at the club and who they are in their homes. The meme creator establishes that men display wealth and gratify their desires and lust in public to create a fascinating impression by onlookers especially women even if it means not being able to meet their necessary needs.
Men as socially unreal
Men as socially unreal

In Fig. 18, the male gender is presented as deceptive. The text producer uses reported speech indicated by past forms of verbs to present the case and also employs non-specificity as seen in the choice of ‘one’ to present the male actor as anonymous. The choice of the verb ‘inboxed’ to represent sending message presupposes that the message is personalized to the lady and is associated with secrecy. The noun ‘boy’ representing the male actor implies that the girl sees him as inexperienced and incapable of sustaining his words. The female in the joke makes this obvious by sending her account details to which the boy responded with ‘unfollowing’ her. The female deliberately exposes the weakness of the male actor by daring him to make her smile by providing her needs. The response from the man is captured in ‘unfollowing’ her, which implies complete disengagement. This response is the punch line of the joke. In the meme, men represented by the boy are presented as people who say what they do not mean just to get what they want. It is clear from the boy’s response that he never meant what he said about making her happy for life but is looking for a way to capture her heart and get what he wants from her. The question ‘whatai do’ is jocular and sarcastic. It is intended to make mockery of the male in question and by extension, the other male in that category.
Men as emotionally unreal
Men as emotionally unreal

In addition to this, male domination that is an integral part of hegemonic masculinity resurfaces in the meme. The man's idea of making a woman smile is to be determined by him not the woman. Hence, the man wants to make the woman smile on his own terms not on the terms of the woman. This shows that the man feels superior and probably thinks he knows what is best for the woman without asking her for her opinion. His response also shows that he finds the woman overbearing which makes her unfit for the kind of happiness he can give.

Figure 19 describes men as superficial and this is evident in the description of their physical appearance. The text producer refers to the attractive body using the adjectives ‘tall and handsome’ and slangy expressions, such as ‘head game’, ‘lit’, ‘sex game’, ‘dope as crack’, and ‘let me sit on your face beards’. The choice of formal expressions in the first sentence followed by slangy expressions implies that the message is for all women interested in physically attractive men. However, the meme creator tries to emphasize that although such men are desirable, the quality of being good for a man goes beyond the physical appearance and sexual prowess. The rhetorical question ‘does he pray?’ is the punch line, which is a departure from the qualities described in the build-up. It submerges those qualities to emphasize prayer, which is believed to be an essential quality for men. The rhetorical question is meant to be thought provoking and move the attention of women from the superficial appearance of men. The implication is that desirable physical appearance does not often reflect a man’s true identity. Therefore, men are given the unreal identity based on the disparity in their appearance and their true identity.
Men as superficial
Men as superficial

The study identified and discussed the manifestations and constructions of a gender’s perception of the other gender on social media. This is achieved through comparative investigation of identities created for a gender by the other gender. Five ‘other’ identities, namely the dependent other, the irrational other, the opportunistic other, the weak other, and the unreal other, are identified in the study. Women are largely conceived by men as irrational, dependent, weak, and unreal while men are largely perceived by women as sometimes irrational, opportunistic, and fake socially and emotionally. In the study, ‘othering’ is used to either reinforce or challenge hegemonic masculinity, which is the prevailing gender ideology in the social context of the data. The genders use humour to create in-group (within gender) ‘other’ identity for advisory purposes or to reprimand while out-group ‘othering’ is used to tease and make mockery of a particular gender. Unlike the feminist conception of ‘otherness’ as exclusively used for females in hegemonic masculinity, this study identified that ‘otherness’ can be used for any of the genders depending on who produces the text, for what purpose and for which audience.

The study aligns with Thielemann’s (2012) assertion that jokes and humour provide a site for the construction and display of gender identities. It also reveals that alongside these constructions, dominant and changing gender paradigms and norms such as gender ‘otherness’ are reflected in humorous texts. Such constructions are motivated by the prevailing gender ideology in the society which in this case is hegemonic masculinity. The identities found in the analysis represent the tension between legitimizing and challenging this ideology especially on social media. The study confirms Holly (2005) and Onadeko’s (2010) findings that there is a tension on the social media with different challenges and reordering of established gender paradigms. Vandergriff’s (2010) view that humour is used as a means of rebellion, resistance to tyranny, or as compensation for defeat is also validated in this study as evident in Correct Bae memes created as the female version and oppositional construct of Correct Bro memes and is intended to give a voice to the female gender on social media and challenge the culture of silence among women.

This study reaffirms that humorous memes perform serious functions, such as identity creation and re-presentation of ideology. Also, the study asserts that there is a reorientation of women through the social media, which serves as a platform for asserting themselves and challenging hegemonic masculinity. However, it is clear that Nigerian men are still generally patriarchal in orientation and not much has changed in their perception of women as clear from the identities created for women in the memes.
